case_vignette: A 35-year-old African American female presents for evaluation of a painless tongue growth present for the past three months. She denies biting the site or any inciting trauma. She noted it when brushing her teeth and it has slowly grown in size. Physical examination reveals a pink nodule on the right mid-tongue. An excisional biopsy is performed and reveals pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia and collections of large polygonal cells with abundant cytoplasm and small cytoplasmic inclusions in the dermis.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painless growth on my tongue that I've noticed for the past three months.
Have you experienced any changes in the size, color, or texture of the growth?
It has slowly grown in size since I first noticed it.
Has there been any bleeding or ulceration from this growth?
No, there's been no bleeding or ulceration.
Do you have any history of tobacco use or excessive alcohol consumption?
No, I do not have a history of using tobacco or drinking excessively.
Have you experienced any recent weight loss, night sweats, or reduced appetite?
No, I haven't experienced any of those symptoms.
Do you have difficulty in speaking or chewing because of the growth?
No, I don't have any difficulty speaking or chewing.
Do you have any history of similar issues or other oral lesions?
No, I've never had similar issues or other oral lesions before.
Is there any history of cancer or similar growths in your family?
I didn't mention any family history of cancer or similar growths.
Do you have any other medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
I didn't mention any other medical conditions or medications that I'm taking.
Is the growth localized to one area of the tongue or does it appear to be spreading?
The growth is localized to one area of my tongue.
Final Diagnosis: Benign lingual papilloma.

trial_2.summarized_conversation: A patient presented to the clinic with a painless growth on the tongue that had been there for about three months. The growth had slowly increased in size since first noticed. The patient denied any changes in taste, numbness, or tingling. There was no history of tobacco or alcohol use in the patient's medical history, and no family history of oral or skin conditions. The patient also denied any trauma, recent oral infections, difficulty swallowing or speaking, or similar growths elsewhere on the body or in the mouth. An excisional biopsy revealed pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia and collections of large cells with abundant cytoplasm and small inclusions inside the cells in the deeper layer of the skin.
trial_2.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Benign tongue lesion; require further evaluation for specific type (e.g., fibroma, papilloma, or other benign tumor).
trial_2.summarized_frq: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the tongue.
